stance_1: I am concerned about health risks from fatty meats
stance_2: I avoid fatty and fried meats
justification: The concern about health risks from fatty meats explicitly supports the avoidance of fatty and fried meats.

stance_1: I am concerned about health risks from fatty meats
stance_2: I try to eat more lean meats
justification: The concern about fatty meats' health risks supports the choice to eat more lean meats.

stance_1: I am concerned about health risks from fatty meats
justification: Concern about health risks from certain meats can implicitly conflict with eating meat daily, but the interviewee resolves this by choosing lean meats.

stance_1: I avoid fatty and fried meats
stance_2: I try to eat more lean meats
justification: Avoiding fatty and fried meats aligns with and supports trying to eat more lean meats.

stance_1: I cannot tolerate beans as before
justification: Reduced tolerance for beans implicitly supports eating meat daily to meet protein needs.

stance_1: I cannot tolerate beans as before
stance_2: I want to get enough protein
justification: The inability to tolerate beans is explicitly linked to needing to get enough protein from other sources.

stance_1: I did not like meat when younger
stance_2: I have increased my meat intake
justification: The interviewee explicitly states a shift from disliking meat to increasing intake.

stance_1: I did not like meat when younger
stance_2: I enjoy certain types of meat
justification: The interviewee notes always liking some types of meat even when generally disliking it as a child.

stance_2: I have increased my meat intake
justification: Eating meat every day is directly supported by having increased meat intake over time.

stance_2: I want to get enough protein
justification: Eating meat daily is explicitly motivated by the desire to get enough protein.

stance_1: I have increased my meat intake
stance_2: I want to get enough protein
justification: Increasing meat intake is explicitly justified as a way to ensure sufficient protein.

stance_1: I believe non-meat foods lack enough protein
stance_2: I want to get enough protein
justification: Belief that non-meat foods lack protein directly motivates effort to get enough protein from meat.

stance_1: I believe non-meat foods lack enough protein
justification: Belief that non-meat foods lack protein supports daily meat consumption.

stance_1: I believe non-meat foods lack enough protein
stance_2: I have increased my meat intake
justification: Belief in insufficient protein from non-meat foods supports increased meat intake.

stance_1: I believe non-meat foods lack enough protein
stance_2: I cannot tolerate beans as before
justification: Reduced tolerance for beans, combined with the belief that non-meat foods lack protein, further justifies reliance on meat.

stance_1: I read health and nutrition information
stance_2: I have increased my meat intake
justification: Reading health and nutrition information is described as a driver for increased meat intake.

stance_1: I read health and nutrition information
stance_2: I want to get enough protein
justification: Reading health and nutrition information supports focus on protein intake.

stance_1: I read health and nutrition information
stance_2: I believe non-meat foods lack enough protein
justification: Health and nutrition reading supports the belief that non-meat foods lack sufficient protein.

stance_1: I enjoy certain types of meat
stance_2: Most people I know eat meat for enjoyment
justification: The interviewee explicitly enjoys certain meats, and this is consistent with the reported motivations of most people known to them.
